This event demonstrates switch synchronization.
By adding <sync> to the switch's name, the switch
will be saved to the server’s database, preserving the
event’s state even after the game restarts.

This event demonstrates that it’s possible to change
an actor's class, name, and graphics, with these
updates synchronized to the server and database.
This event demonstrates a global switch. By adding
<global> to the switch's name, the switch will be
shared across all players and remain unique for
everyone in the game.

This event demonstrates that events with the <Sync>
tag in their note will be synchronized for all players
on the same map.
This event demonstrates that jumps are also synchronized.

By adding <SelfSwitches> to the event's note, it
will be saved to the server’s database, preserving the
event’s state even after the game restarts.

This event demonstrates that jumps are also synchronized.
This is the resource delay in seconds and is
in game time, not in real time. Configure the
value you want.
This will calculate when resource will be available.
You must have a unique <Sync> variable for each
resource to control it's time.
Resource Delay and Available Time variables can be
reused in other events, they're used only for
local calculations. Timestamp variable must be
configured in Time Plugin.
Resource is available, we will reset <Sync> variable
time and give the resource.
Nature
Your Potion is ready, take it!
Resource is not available yet.
Nature
I'm making a potion for you, come back later
to pick it up.
This event demonstrates how to create a resource that
is only available from time to time. For each resource,
a <Sync> variable must be created, which should be
updated in two places within the event: during the
calculation of the Available Time, and when resetting
the variable.
If the variable is <Global>, the resource collection
will be shared globally among all players.
This event essentially checks when the resource was
last collected (Pot Last Time) and adds this value to
the time required for the resource to become available
again (Resource Delay), resulting in the Available Time.
If the resource is available (Timestamp > Available Time),
the collection time is updated (Pot Last Time = Timestamp)
and the resource is granted to the player.
This event demonstrates a party switch. By adding
<party> to the switch's name, the switch will be
shared across party members and remain unique for
everyone in the party.
